Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery little-master cup; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; top of lip glazed; exterior: myrtle leaf pattern on lip; black bamd at top of handle zone.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the decorative motif finds parallels with his South Ionian little master cups and South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9B. Type 9B cups correspond to Attic Siana, band, and Gordion cups. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. Type 5 cups are rare at Naukratis whereas there are numerous examples of Type 9 cups. Both types were common drinking vessels found in Greeks sanctuaries, including the sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus. Hayes suggested a Rhodian origin for these types of cups but this is uncertain (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 114). Schlotzhauer points out that the same myrtle pattern is found on Fikellura style pottery from Miletus and thus suggest a South Ionian or more specifically Milesian origin for the cups (Schlotzhauer 2012, 108-9).
Bibliographic references: CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 77, no. 29, pl. I)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.825) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
